[frustrated] Your Majesty, that speech wasn't just controversial, it was, [exasperated], political suicide wrapped in royal purple.
[resolute] Um, maybe it's time someone in this palace stopped, well, pretending everything is fine while our people suffer.

The nobility is already, [urgent], drafting letters calling for your abdication, and I mean, the military commanders are, [worried], conspicuously silent which is never, [grave], a good sign, you know.
[steady] So, um, what would you have me do—take it all back and, well, bow to their threats like every weak monarch before me?

[pleading] I'd have you survive long enough to, [careful], actually implement these reforms instead of becoming a, [bitter], martyr that changes nothing except who sits on, well, your throne tomorrow, I mean.

[fierce] I'd rather rule for one year with, [passionate], integrity than spend decades as a puppet dancing while, um, the same corrupt ministers pull my, [bitter], strings, you know.

[weary] The people's support won't mean much when tanks roll through the palace gates.
[quiet] You sound like you've already chosen a side.
[offended] I'm trying to save your life because despite your recklessness you're the first monarch in a century who actually gives a damn.
If they remove me, [resigned], who takes the throne—my cousin Marcus who's basically a puppet already, you know?
[grim] Exactly.
[resolved] Then we fight.
[reluctant] Well, if we're doing this, um, we need to move fast—secure the treasury, [urgent], get the city guard on our side before the generals make their move.

[resigned] I've served three monarchs and watched two of them fall because they, [sad], lacked the courage to change anything that mattered, so maybe, [hopeful], it's time I backed someone foolish enough to, um, actually try, you know.
